George Lopez's comedy special ""The Wall"" airs tonight on HBO.

(SOUNDBITE OF WAR'S ""LOW RIDER"")
On the campaign trail, pressure continues on the so-called superdelegates, who will likely decide whether Barack Obama or Hillary Clinton is the Democratic presidential nominee.
We call this the backroom primary, and we've been finding out who these superdelegates are and how they will make their choices.
NPR's Howard Berkes spoke with a superdelegate in Utah torn between her commitement to Clinton and her state's primary vote for Obama.
Helen Langan is getting super pressure about being a superdelegate.
(Soundbite of phone ringing)
I have to put her on speaker(ph).
There's voicemail every day.
Some of these superdelegates aren't even going with the majority of the people in their area.
I think that's a very selfish thing for a superdelegate.
There are e-mails every day.
This came yesterday.
I have absolutely nothing against Senator Clinton.
If she were the party's nominee, I would gladly support her.
Please join Democrats in Utah in support of Senator Obama.
There are political messages left on Langan's MySpace page, which is devoted to her upcoming wedding.

Obviously not people we know, which is kind of what made it so funny and surprising for my fiance when he opened it up and, you know, found messages from total strangers about the presidential election, asking me to support Senator Obama.
And there's even that husband-to-be.
He's been writing responses and telling me.
He's like, I told them that don't worry, man, I'm working on her.
You know, I'm an Obama supporter, too.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Langan is a 31-year-old spokeswoman for Salt Lake City's Democratic mayor.
She spent two years in the press office of President Clinton.
She's a national Democratic committeewoman, which automatically makes her a superdelegate, and she endorsed Hillary Clinton in October, after a seven-year-old niece asked her this:
...That they were elated.
You mean the lawyers for the victims as opposed to...
There are two pos--he said his first choice is to land here at Kennedy.
There's one opportunity just after 5 AM Eastern time, and another landing opportunity at around 6:45 Eastern.

And the backup plan is to bring it in at Edwards Air Force Base in California, which has more reliable weather and the weather for there looks good and landing times are around 8:15 and 9:47, I have right now.
So if the landing does not work tomorrow in Florida, they wouldn't wait yet another day, they would just go ahead and put it down at Edwards?
Right.
They really want to put it down tomorrow because they have--the supplies start to run out on Wednesday.
So Wednesday is a real backup.
They're gonna really try and bring it down one place or another tomorrow.
Now does this one-day delay mean any big changes for the flight path or what happens with the orbiter?
Actually it does change the flight path.
The ground path for today cut sort of Northeast, it used to go through Central America, over Cuba to Florida, that was for today.
Tomorrow the landing is going to be--the landing path would take it more West to East.
It goes across Mexico, then over the Gulf of Mexico, and basically skirts the Southern coast of the United States and then west to east over Florida and lands here on the Atlantic coast.
This is one thing that has changed since Columbia is that they're now taking into account public safety.
So during Columbia some 85,000 pounds of debris fell from the sky and nobody got hit, but the idea now is to fly in over the ocean or unpopulated areas or at least avoid big cities.
We're talking to NPR's David Kestenbaum.
He's at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida where they're waiting another day for the arrival of the shuttle Discovery.
And, David, of course, one of the reasons that we're watching so closely here today is because the last shuttle mission ended in disaster in 2003.
This was billed as the return to flight.
How has it gone overall so far?
You know, NASA said they're very happy with things; obviously, they'll be a lot happier when it lands.
You know, until it's over, it's not over.
But a lot of the mission has been devoted to making sure these new safety systems they put in are working.
They delivered supplies to the space station, they fixed their gyroscope and that was all good.

But their top priority was really to inspect the heat resistant tiles on the underside of the space shuttle, then Eileen Collins had the space shuttle do a back flip as it was approaching the space station before it docked so the astronauts on the space station could take pictures of the underside, and they really went through, as they said, every fiber of the bottom and the leading edge of the wing.

So that now in some ways they're more confident than they have been in the past because they know what the bottom of the shuttle looks like and they feel very confident that it's a clean bird, as they say, and they're expecting a very smooth landing.
Are there any doubts, any questions that you know of as we prepare for this landing attempt tomorrow?
No.
I mean, everybody--the astronauts have said, you know, they expected to go just as they've rehearsed and the people on the ground have--they said they've rehearsed this literally hundreds of times.
This specific landing hundreds of times.
I suppose if there were any doubts they wouldn't go ahead, they'd try something else.
Yup.
They're going to bring it down tomorrow one way or the other.
That's what it looks like.
OK.
Thanks, David.
You're welcome.
That's NPR's David Kestenbaum at Kennedy Space Center in Florida.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
Another day in court and another combative performance from Saddam Hussein.
The former Iraqi leader was in the dock for the third time today on trial along with seven others for crimes against humanity.
Specifically, he's being tried for the killing of 148 people from the town of Dujail.
Those killings followed an attempt on Saddam's life.
NPR's Jamie Tarabay has our story from Baghdad.
If Saddam is convicted of ordering the 1982 massacre in Dujail, he could get the death penalty.
But as the former dictator made clear to everyone watching, that's something he won't be dreading.
(Through Translator) I'm not afraid of execution.
Execution is cheaper than the shoe of an Iraqi.
That shoe reference carries a heavy insult among Arabs.
Saddam commanded the floor at the end of a day full of high drama, raised voices, angry accusations and insults.
(Through Translator) I swear in the name of God almighty that I will witness with all frankness and I won't say anything but the truth.
Along with millions of Iraqis glued to their television screens, Saddam listened to the testimony of the first live witness in his case.
Ahmed Hassan Mohammed appeared before the court and, perilously for him, on camera.
Mohammed, now in his mid-30s with gray in his beard, recalled how his family was tortured and imprisoned after the failed attempt on Saddam's life in Dujail.
The witness said intelligence officers gave his teen-age brother Hussein(ph) electric shocks as his elderly father was forced to watch.
(Arabic spoken)
Mohammed was clearly emotional as he spoke.
He said, `My brother was tortured then killed.'
